summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by The New York Times Company in a FOIA lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The Times argues that the BOP has failed to justify withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide under various FOIA exemptions. The document details the legal arguments against the BOP's use of Exemptions 7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, and 7(E) to withhold records. This document is a legal filing from The New York Times Company, likely a reply brief or opposition, in a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) lawsuit against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP). The Times argues that BOP's justifications for withholding documents related to suicide prevention procedures are insufficient, citing publicly available information and legal precedent. The filing concludes with a request for the court to order disclosure, award costs, and grant other relief.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was involved in an apparent suicide attempt while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein's Death by Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide, hanging himself in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Filing of Reply Memorandum
events.description: The New York Times Company filed this reply memorandum in further support of its cross-motion for summary judgment in its FOIA lawsuit against the BOP.

events.title: Filing of Plaintiff's Legal Brief
events.description: The New York Times Company's attorneys file a legal brief (likely a reply or opposition) in their FOIA lawsuit (Case 1:20-cv-00833-PAE) seeking documents from the Bureau of Prisons.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, New York (MCC)
New York, NY 10018 (The New York Times Company Legal Department)
keyFacts: The BOP is withholding approximately 3,500 pages of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide in response to a FOIA request from The New York Times.

Withheld records include emails about Epstein's mental/physical health, details of his incarceration, reports on his suicide attempt and death, correspondence with his cellmate's attorneys, and Epstein's medical/psychological records.

The BOP's primary justification for withholding is Exemption 7(A), citing potential interference with the prosecutions of Nicholas Tartaglione (Epstein's former cellmate) and two correctional officers who failed to perform counts.

The document argues that the BOP has failed to demonstrate a 'rational nexus' between the administrative prison records and the cited law enforcement proceedings, or that release would cause foreseeable harm.
The document cites public statements from Epstein's brother calling for the release of records related to the suicide, countering the BOP's claim of a privacy interest.
The document is part of a FOIA lawsuit (Case 1:20-cv-00833-PAE) brought by The New York Times Company against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP).

The Times argues that BOP's use of exemptions to withhold documents related to suicide prevention procedures is invalid because similar information is already publicly available from the Department of Justice.

The legal argument cites specific cases (Coleman v. FBI, Shapiro v. Dep't of Justice, Am. Immigration Lawyers Ass'n v. Dept of Homeland Sec.) to challenge the government's justification for non-disclosure.
The filing requests the court to order BOP to disclose the documents, award The Times its costs and attorneys' fees, and grant any other just relief.
